attributes.title: How is accessibility to cities influencing biodiversity change?
attributes.description: Globally, biodiversity is changing in complex ways in a time of accelerating human impact. We know little about how large scale anthropogenic activity, as a prominent contemporary global change driver, is influencing the reshuffling of ecological communities. I quantify the influence on ecological assemblages by human activities, such as roads and urbanisation, worldwide and across taxa by analysing change in 181 time series studies. I predict to find higher temporal and spatial turnover with greater exposure to roads and urbanisation. Linking human impact with biodiversity change can provide the needed evidence and predictions for better international policy making in the light of our rapidly changing Anthropocene.

q1.value: How is accessibility to cities influencing biodiversity change?

q3.value:
Background
Globally, biodiversity is changing in complex ways in a time of accelerating human impact. We know little about how large scale anthropogonic activity, as a prominent contemporary global change driver, is indirectly influencing the current reshuffling of ecological communities. Direct environmental influences, such as forest loss and warming, have been found to catalyse biodiversity changes. Quantifying the indirect impact of global changes of human activity, such as roads and urbanisation, will allow to better unravel different sources of heterogenous biodiversity change. Urbanisation and roads can influence changes in ecological communities by increasing connectivity and favouring urban-adapted species, causing both temporal and spatial turnover. Species’ response to such influences is dependent on ecological aspects such as their mobility. Highly mobile species are found to be affected most by urbanisation. Beyond the effect of urbanisation and roads on biodiversity change, high human population density often coincides with high species richness, illuminating spatial congruence between human development and diverse ecosystems. This can be seen both as a threat and as an opportunity to improved management. Recent global-scale data compilations of biodiversity time-series (BioTIME) and data sets which indirectly capture large-scale anthropogenic activities, will allow me to quantify their influence on ecological communities worldwide. Linking human impact with biodiversity change can provide the needed evidence and predictions for better international policy making in the light of our rapidly changing Anthropocene.

Purpose of the study
My aim is to quantify how global change drivers influence ecological communities (and individual taxa) over time. Specifically, I will focus on the effects of urbanisation and roads, captured in the metric accessibility to cities, and human population density on temporal changes on ecological community composition overall and across taxa. These drivers are an indirect representation of large- scale human activity and capture big parts of the alteration of our planet. I will test if these drivers of global change explain heterogenous biodiversity change found across our planet.

Research questions

1.	Do sites with higher accessibility to cities experience more changes in assemblage composition over time (temporal turnover) than locations with lower accessibility?

a.	How does the duration of ecological monitoring influence the magnitude of detected temporal turnover trends?

2.	How does temporal turnover of ecological communities respond to levels of accessibility across taxa (birds, mammals, terrestrial invertebrates, terrestrial plants)?

3.	How is temporal turnover influenced by an interaction between human population density and accessibility?

If time allows look at population level analysis (choosing the 3 most abundant populations from the datasets used above)

4.	Do sites with higher accessibility to cities experience more changes in population trends than locations with lower accessibility?

a.	How does the duration of ecological monitoring influence the magnitude of detected population trends?

5.	How do population trends of ecological communities respond to levels of accessibility across taxa (birds, mammals, terrestrial invertebrates, terrestrial plants)?

6.	How are population trends influenced by an interaction between human population density and accessibility?

q4.value:
Definition of terms used

An ecological assemblage is a collection of species occurring in the same place at the same time, sharing the same phylogeny.

Turnover is the change of species identity of an ecological composition, calculated in the final year of each time series relative to the first.

Population trends are the overall trends in the abundance of an individual species across the duration of each time-series.

For all hypotheses, turnover can be replaced with population trends.

1.	Do sites with higher accessibility to cities experience more changes in community composition over time (temporal turnover) than locations with lower accessibility?
Hypotheses

•	Sites with higher accessibility to cities correspond with greater temporal turnover
•	The magnitude of temporal turnover increases for sites which have been monitored over longer durations
I predict greater temporal turnover with greater exposure of accessibility to cities, as an alteration of the natural environment benefits some species, while damaging others, influencing community composition. 

I predict greater temporal turnover in sites which have been monitored over longer durations, as the effect of turnover becomes more apparent over time.

2.	How does temporal turnover of ecological communities respond to levels of accessibility across taxa (birds, mammals, terrestrial invertebrates, terrestrial plants)?
Hypothesis

•	Ecological communities of taxa respond differently to high and low levels of accessibility.
I predict both positive and negative trends to be present.

3.	How is temporal turnover influenced by an interaction between human population density and accessibility?
Hypothesis

•	The relationship between accessibility to cities and temporal turnover is steeper, when human population density is higher
I predict the relationship between accessibility and temporal turnover to be steeper, when human population density is higher, as high HPD increases the pressures on the natural systems, leading to higher turnover.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In my analysis I will test the relationships between accessibility to cities and 1) temporal turnover, 2) taxa’s individual response and 3) the interaction of human population density on temporal turnover. My analysis will include observational studies of assemblage compositions over time from the terrestrial realms only, with no manipulative experiments included. I will include data from 91 studies, with 5788 plots in 1023 unique locations. The time-series used represent repeated studies of species abundance and identity of all species found within an ecological community. The data collection of BioTIME was consistent within studies but not between studies.

The BioTIME database is limited in its even representation of different taxa and latitudes. It underrepresents reptiles and amphibians and the tropics and polar regions (see Figure 1).

I will extract the accessibility score over ~1km² grid cells around each location of available biodiversity time-series.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
All my data exist already. I will be the first to integrate the different databases together in this way. The BioTIME database is openly accessible on their website (http://biotime.st-andrews.ac.uk/). The accessibility to cities is available through the malariaatlas research website (https://malariaatlas.org/research-project/accessibility_to_cities/).

I have looked at meta-data only to figure out sample sizes, but I have not conducted any of the analysis. I visualized the meta-data of the BioTIME time-series in Figure 1.

question.value: All my data is readily available online and accessible to anyone, since all databases are open source. I will not conduct any first-hand data collection myself. I will use the biodiversity time series data from the BioTIME database. All further analysis will be conducted in R. I will include all available data that meet my criteria.

q13.value:
I will combine records from 91 studies, with 5788 plots in 1023 unique locations of community composition as well as the accessibility to cities score and human population density at each site. The sample sizes for different taxa can be found in Table 1. The spatial and temporal scales for sample sizes can be found in Table 2. As the BioTIME database is continuously updated, more data might become available. I will use all the data available as of the 03/03/2020.

Taxa	Studies	 Plots	Observations
Birds	10	842	107366
Mammals	11	1145	36433
Terrestrial invertebrates	9	314	26148
Terrestrial plants	61	3487	116832
Total	91	5788	286779

Table 2: Mean spatial and temporal scales of sample sizes.
Spatial scale	Mean plots per study	63.60
	Mean observation per plot	22991.77
Temporal scale	Mean years per study	20.18
	Mean data points per study	11.1

q14.value: N/A – I will use all data available which fit my criteria: part of the terrestrial realm, at least 2 survey points in time, minimum time-series duration of 5 years and having at least 15 studies per taxa.

question.value: N/A

Response variable: 
•	Temporal turnover: changes in species composition due to replacement over time, calculated as the comparison in the final year of each time-series relative to the first.

•	Population trends: overall trend in population abundance over time.

Explanatory variables: 
•	The accessibility to cities scores for the 1km² around the location of the biodiversity record
•	The mean human population density scores for the 1km² around the location of the biodiversity record
•	The interaction term between accessibility and human population density
•	Duration

Random variables:
•	Taxa
•	Broad grid cell
•	Study ID

Examples of all variables can be found in the sample data csv file in the appendix.
The accessibility to cities score is derived from multiple layers of input data. For more details on the method behind the database, see Weiss et al., 2018.

I will use hierarchical models in a Bayesian framework in R. First, I will calculate temporal turnover trends. The outcome of these calculations will be used subsequently and tested against accessibility scores. The specific structure of the statistical model is outlined below. The model includes weakly informative priors.

temporal turnover ~ accessibility + duration + accessibility:human population density, human population density, area?; random = (accessibility|taxa), grid cell, study ID/plot

The models will be based on a zero one inflated beta distribution.

I will run the model first with both random intercepts and slopes but if no model convergence can be achieved, I will run them with only random intercept. 

I will initially run models with one chain of 100 000 iterations with a warmup of 10 000 iterations and will increase these metrics if convergence is not achieved. I will assess convergence visually by examining the trace plots.


1.	Do sites with higher accessibility to cities experience more changes in community composition over time (temporal turnover) than locations with lower accessibility?
where temporal turnover is calculated as the change in community composition due to species replacement, based on the final year of each biodiversity time-series relative to the first. Turnover is based on Jaccard’s dissimilarity metric, where zero means no change in community composition and one means complete change of species. 


2.	How does temporal turnover of ecological communities respond to levels of accessibility across taxa (birds, mammals, terrestrial invertebrates, terrestrial plants)?
For details on model structure, distribution and priors, see beginning of section.


3.	How is temporal turnover influenced by an interaction between human population density and accessibility?

For details on model structure, distribution and priors, see beginning of section.


Additional analysis
•	Accessibilities sensitivity to buffer size
•	Temporal mismatch of data: analysis with less data, e.g. including only data from 1970 – 2010

q20.value:
The extracted accessibility values will be scales between zero and one. Zero means a very low accessibility and one means very high accessibility.

Human population density will also be scaled between zero and one. Zero means a very low human population density and one means a high human population density.

To account for spatial autocorrelation, a random broad grid cell will be included. This grid cell is based on ~ 100km² hexagon cells.

q21.value: As I will be using a Bayesian framework, my inferences will be based on the posterior distribution of each fixed effect. They will be considered significant if the lower and upper 95% credible intervals don’t overlap zero. I will conclude all results, regardless of the direction or magnitude of the effect size.

q22.value: I will include all data that fit my criteria.

q23.value: There is no missing data per se as the accessibility dataset is global. There are temporal mismatches though between the biodiversity time-series and the one-point nominal measuring point of accessibility in 2015. The durations of the time-series vary and go back to early 20th century. The accessibility score can be considered a cumulative variable. In order to analyze the influence of the temporal mismatch of the BioTIME time series with the accessibility score, I will conduct a sensitivity analysis which will only include data from the BioTIME data set from 1970 - 2010.

attributes.title: Sanità Pubblica e Medicina Termale: tradizione, evidenze ed opportunità
attributes.description: La presente trattazione ha l’obiettivo principale di aggiornare le evidenze scientifiche sull’efficacia delle cure termali nel trattamento di varie condizioni morbose attraverso una valutazione critica dei risultati delle revisioni sistematiche e meta-analisi sull’argomento.

q2.value: To test whether treatments with mineral waters and therapeutic mud employed in spa centers have any demonstrated beneficial effect on various clinical conditions.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Umbrella review (systematic review of systematic reviews and meta-analyses)

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
PICOS criteria:
Population: patients with any health condition diagnosed in accordance with validated standards.
Intervention: any type of intervention employing mineral waters, therapeutic mud and their derivatives (inhalation therapy, balneo-therapy, mud-therapy, topical applications...). 
Comparison: any type.
Outcomes: any relevant clinical outcome, including symptoms and functionality improvement, reduction in drug consumption, and quality-of-life amelioration.
Study design: systematic reviews and meta-analyses.

Searched databases: Medline, EMBASE, Web of Science, Cochrane Library, and Google Scholar.
Date of search: January 7th, 2020.
PubMed search strategy: balneotherapy[Title/Abstract] OR hydrotherapy[Title/Abstract] OR thalassotherapy[Title/Abstract] OR “spa therapy”[Title/Abstract] OR “water therapy”[Title/Abstract] OR “aquatic therapy”[Title/Abstract] OR “mud therapy”[Title/Abstract] OR “peloid therapy”[Title/Abstract] OR psammotherapy[Title/Abstract] OR “inhalation therapy”[Title/Abstract] OR “endotympanic insufflation”[Title/Abstract] OR “politzer”[Title/Abstract] OR “cave therapy”[Title/Abstract] OR hydropinotherapy[Title/Abstract] OR “mineral water*”[Title/Abstract] OR “thermal water*”[Title/Abstract] OR “hot spring water*”[Title/Abstract]

Synthesis of results: data will be qualitatively summarized and critically discussed.

Symptoms (in particular: pain), clinical signs (objectively measured with dedicated biomedical tools), laboratory parameters, functionality (in particular: range of motion, disability, cardio-respiratory function), drug consumption, psychological health (in particular: mood), Quality of Life (in particular: health-related QoL).

Results of included systematic reviews will be only qualitatively synthesized, after a critical evaluation based on the NIH (National Institutes of Health) tool. See: https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/study-quality-assessment-tools

q21.value: When relevant data of included reviews are missing, authors will be contacted by email to retrieve essential information regarding their study.

attributes.title: Identifying resource intensive areas of systematic review production and updating – a scoping review
attributes.description: We aim to conduct a formal scoping review of the published literature assessing the resource intensity of each step of the systematic review process.

q1.value: Identifying resource intensive areas of systematic review production and updating – a scoping review

q2.value: Barbara Nussbaumer-Streit, Ellen Moriah, Irma Klerings, Gerald Gartlehner, James Thomas, Lone Ramer Mikkelsen, Nicoletta Riva, Lisa Affengruber, Silva AG, Eduard Baladia, Maria Marques, Patricia Martínez, Luis Aguilar, Roland Garroz, Rodrigo Martínez-Rodríguez, Liliya Eugenevna Ziganshina, Meropi Kontogiani, Sousa M, Angelos Kassianos, Geoff Frampton, Rigmor Berg, Mersiha, Rene Spjker

q3.value: The aim of this scoping review is to identify the most resource intensive areas when conducting or updating a SR in order to find out where the largest gain in improving efficiency whilst sustaining quality might be possible. In addition, we would like to know why these areas are resource intensive in order to identify suitable methods to address them. The authors of this protocol have not found any robust reviews available on this topic, which calls for an exploratory review.

q4.value:
1.	How many resources do different steps of the systematic review process consume?
2.	What are reasons why steps of the systematic review process are resource intense?

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will conduct a scoping review. Within EVBRES we define a scoping review as a form of knowledge synthesis that addresses an exploratory research question aimed at mapping key concepts, theories, types and sources of evidence, and gaps in research related to a defined area or field by systematically searching, selecting, and synthesizing existing knowledge. Thus, the scoping review will be conducted following the guidance given by Arksey and O`Malley (2005) and Levac, Colquhoun and O`Brian (2010). 

Arksey H, O'Malley L. Scoping studies: towards a methodological framework. International Journal of Social Research Methodology. 2005;8(1):19-32.

Levac D, Colquhoun H, O'Brien KK. Scoping studies: advancing the methodology. Implementation science : IS. 2010;5:69.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
The search for this scoping review will follow the three-step process recommended by the Joanna Briggs institute (2019): In a first step, we conducted a limited, focused, search of Ovid MEDLINE. The team is currently (Jan 2020) screening search results. The team will analyze relevant studies to identify additional relevant text words and subject headings. 

A second, comprehensive, search using all identified keywords and index terms will be undertaken across the following databases: Ovid MEDLINE, Scopus (Elsevier), Science Citation Index Expanded, Social Sciences Citation Index, and Current Contents Connect (via Web of Science). 
An information specialist will conduct all database searches. The comprehensive MEDLINE strategy will be reviewed in accordance with the PRESS Peer Review of Electronic Search Strategies guideline by another information specialist (2016).

In a third step, the reference list of identified reports and articles will be screened for additional studies. We will also select studies to conduct further reference chasing, i.e. forward citation tracking (e.g., via Scopus or Web of Science) or similarity searches (e.g., via PubMed or Google Scholar). 

In addition, to identify grey literature, we will search for dissertations and theses via ProQuest Dissertations & Theses Global. We will also conduct a handsearch of relevant conference proceedings (e.g., the Cochrane Colloquium, HTAi).
Finally, authors of selected articles will be approached through email as an expert source of articles of interest.

Inclusion criteria:

Population/Topic: 
- Focus on resource use when producing or updating a systematic review (mentioned in title or abstract)
Concept: 
- Assessing one or more of the steps mentioned in Table 1
Outcomes:
- Time spent on diverse tasks (overall, time per person)
- Effort of personnel
- Monetary resources
- Material used
- Perceived reasons why some steps are resource intense

registration_responses.q3: The aim of this scoping review is to identify the most resource intensive areas when conducting or updating a SR in order to find out where the largest gain in improving efficiency whilst sustaining quality might be possible. The authors of this protocol have not found any robust reviews available on this topic, which calls for an exploratory review.

registration_responses.q8.question:
We will conduct a scoping review. Within EVBRES we define a scoping review as a form of knowledge synthesis that addresses an exploratory research question aimed at mapping key concepts, theories, types and sources of evidence, and gaps in research related to a defined area or field by systematically searching, selecting, and synthesizing existing knowledge. Thus, the scoping review will be conducted following the guidance given by Arksey and O`Malley (2005) and Levac, Colquhoun and O`Brian (2010). 

Arksey H, O'Malley L. Scoping studies: towards a methodological framework. International Journal of Social Research Methodology. 2005;8(1):19-32.

Levac D, Colquhoun H, O'Brien KK. Scoping studies: advancing the methodology. Implementation science : IS. 2010;5:69.
registration_responses.q12.question:
The search for this scoping review will follow the three-step process recommended by the Joanna Briggs institute (2019): In a first step, we conducted a limited, focused, search of Ovid MEDLINE. The team is currently (Jan 2020) screening search results. The team will analyze relevant studies to identify additional relevant text words and subject headings. 

A second, comprehensive, search using all identified keywords and index terms will be undertaken across the following databases: Ovid MEDLINE, Scopus (Elsevier), Science Citation Index Expanded, Social Sciences Citation Index, and Current Contents Connect (via Web of Science). 
An information specialist will conduct all database searches. The comprehensive MEDLINE strategy will be reviewed in accordance with the PRESS Peer Review of Electronic Search Strategies guideline by another information specialist (2016).

In a third step, the reference list of identified reports and articles will be screened for additional studies. We will also select studies to conduct further reference chasing, i.e. forward citation tracking (e.g., via Scopus or Web of Science) or similarity searches (e.g., via PubMed or Google Scholar). 

In addition, to identify grey literature, we will search for dissertations and theses via ProQuest Dissertations & Theses Global. We will also conduct a handsearch of relevant conference proceedings (e.g., the Cochrane Colloquium, HTAi).
Finally, authors of selected articles will be approached through email as an expert source of articles of interest.

attributes.title: Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Pandemic: Protocol of Overview of Systematic Reviews

q1.value: Israel Junior Borges do Nascimento, Milena Soriano Marcolino, Thilo von Groote, Hebatullah Mohamed Abdulazeem, Nathalia Sernizon, Ishanka Weerasekara

q2.value: There is a high number of systematic reviews on the literature associated with the novel coronavirus infection.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q5.value: There is no medical intervention being addressed in the study. We will collect publish data only

question.value:
The methodology used in this review will be based and adapted on Chapter 22 of the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. This overview will be an extension to a recently submitted protocol linked to a PROSPERO publication (CRD42020170623).
The search will be conducted on Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, PubMed, EMBASE, CINAHL (The Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature), Web of Sciences, LILACS (Latin American and Caribbean Health Sciences Literature), PDQ-Evidence, Global Research on Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) from the WHO, and Epistemonikos.  
Criteria for considering reviews for inclusion
We will include any systematic reviews (including or not meta-analysis and without restriction on date of last search) that analyzed primary data from patients infected by the SARS-CoV-2. No restraints will be to impose on the design of primary studies within systematic reviews.  A systematic review is defined by: I. the search was conducted at least in 2 databases (with one being electronic); and II. had a methods section or description with inclusion criteria. All searches, title and abstract screening, as well as records selection, will be performed independently by two investigators using Covidence Platform. Discrepancies will be resolved by consensus. Articles deemed potentially eligible will be retrieved for full-text review. Non-English publications will translate by a native/fluent speaker. Ethics approval will not be necessary. 
Types of participants and type of interventions or approaches will be considered
We will include systematic reviews including original findings from patients infected by the SARS-CoV-2 worldwide. We will include reviews that systematically analyzed diagnostic methods, therapeutic interventions, laboratory and radiological results from patients infected by the virus. We will exclude narrative reviews and reviews with only one author as these were highly unlike to be transparent and methodologically replicable. 
Types of outcomes
We will consider the following outcomes as primary outcomes: all-cause mortality rate, need, and length for mechanical ventilation (yes/no); length of hospitalization (days), admission to the intensive care unit. Exploratory outcomes analyzed will be male to female ratio, clinical symptoms analysis, pharmacological interventions as well as non-pharmacological, diagnostic methods used for the detection of the virus, laboratory findings (blood count cells, liver enzymes, C-reactive protein, d-dimer, albumin, lipid profile, serum ions, vitamins measures, glucose levels, and any important biomarkers) and radiological assessment (using radiography, computed tomography, magnetic resonance or ultrasound). 
Data Collection, Quality Assessment and Data Synthesis
Data extraction and quality assessment will be performed independently by two overview authors. Conflicts will be resolved by consensus or by a third researcher. Identification data (author name and journal of publication), range of period associated with the search, number of databases, population or settings considered, main results and outcomes observed, and number of participants were extracted in an Excel file. Two researchers independently will be to assess the quality of the reviews using an adapted version of the ‘A MeaSurement Tool to Assess systematic Reviews (AMSTAR)’.  We will adapt the before mentioned tool because of the lack of systematic reviews using randomized clinical trials. For data synthesis, we will prepare a table summarizing each included systematic review considering the aim of each study. Therefore, we will prepare a narrative summary of the methods and findings, as well as study strengths and limitations.

attributes.title: Effect of Covid-19 on Measured Risk Preferences

q1.value: Effects of Covid-19 on Measured Risk Preferences

q3.value:
More and more research points to the notion that there is something akin to a general factor of risk preference (Frey et al., 2017; Zhang et al., 2019), but that there can also be domain-specific preferences (Nicholson et al., 2002; Millroth et al., 2020). 

It is, however, unclear to what extent these measured preferences relate to behavior outside of the laboratory, and to what extent changes in the environment outside of the laboratory can contribute to changes in the measured behavior:

-  previous research on stock-market crashes and natural disasters have yielded mixed results (for a review, see Hanaoka et al., 2018). 

The current covid-19 pandemic puts the notions of risk and uncertainty into the absolute center of people's lives, making the situation suitable for making inquiries into these issues.

q4.value:
H1: If Covid-19 contributes to "sharpening" people's risk-senses, then people's measured risk preferences will show more extreme responses during the outbreak, as compared to before and after the outbrek. 

H2: People's risk preferences are so stable that they are not easily affected by the experience of negative rare-events

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
There are two parallel data-collections, one from an AMERICAN SAMPLE and one from a SWEDISH SAMPLE.

The American Sample: 
1. Participants are given instructions and information about the survey.
2. Participants answer questions about income, gender, age, educational level. Used for sample comparisons in the analyses. 
3. Participants report certainty equivalent for two lotteries: one low-probability prospect and one high-probability prospect - as used in my previous research (Millroth et al., 2018; 2019).
4. Participants answer 8 risk-preference questions from the GRiPS (Zhang et al., 2019)
5. Participants answer 6 risk-preferences questions from Nicholson et al. (2002). 
6. Participants answer 7 risk-preferences questions about the frequency or magnitude in which they engage risk-behavior in their daily lives (e.g., number of insurances, proportion of investments placed in stocks vs. bonds). 
7. Participants answer four questions to measure their numeracy (the Berlin Numeracy Test). 
8. Participants answer a number of questions about their attitudes toward the covid-19 pandemic. 

The Swedish Sample:
 Participants are given instructions and information about the survey.
2. Participants answer questions about income, gender, age, educational level. Used for sample comparisons in the analyses. 
3. Participants report willingness-to-pay for a number of lotteries (as part of an undergraduate thesis, prospects not yet decided on).
4. Participants answer 8 risk-preference questions from the GRiPS (Zhang et al., 2019)
5. Participants answer 6 risk-preferences questions from Nicholson et al. (2002). 
6. Participants answer 7 risk-preferences questions about the frequency or magnitude in which they engage risk-behavior in their daily lives (e.g., number of insurances, proportion of investments placed in stocks vs. bonds). 
7. Participants answer four questions to measure their numeracy (the Berlin Numeracy Test). 
8. Participants answer a number of questions about their attitudes toward the covid-19 pandemic.

q9.value: The presentation order of the monetary gambles are randomized for each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
-American  Sample collected from Figure-Eight.com - previously CrowdFlower.com (as in Millroth et al., 2018; 2019)

- Only top contributors (FE have a three-scale ranking, so participants with a rank of 3)
- Only contributors who spend more than two minutes of on the survey. 
- Only participant who have not used weird input on the BNT (e.g., random typing - "fewfew" or same answer to all questions). 
- Only participant who report lowerer certainty equivalent for the low-probability gamble than the high-probability gamble.

These control measures are the same as in Millroth et al., (2018; 2019) and worked well then. 

Swedish Sample:
The survey is distributed through social media

q13.value:
American sample:
200 participants during covid-19 outbreak (maximum collection time = 2 weeks).

200 more participants after clear peak decline. 

Swedish sample:
As many as possible in two weeks. 
Then again after clear peak decline.

q14.value: Money constraint. But should be sufficient to run Bayesian analyses or regressions. If the Bayes factors are uninformative, then the sample size will be increased.

question.value:
CE difference: Low-Probability prospects-High-probability prospects
Summed GRIPS score: Sum of the 8 items for each individual. 
Summed domain-specific risk score: Each individual provide an estimate on each of the six domains
Summed real-life risk frequency/magnitude measure: The participants' z-scores for each item is identified and then all z-scores for an individual are summed. 
Summed covid-19 attitudes: All items are summed to one score for each individual

BAYESIAN STATISTICS ONLY!

American Sample:

1. Evalutions of the two prospects will be compared with previous data (Millroth et al., 2018; 2019), where the CE difference between the low-probability and high-probability prospect provide a raw estimate of their risk attitude and serve as the dependent variable in a regression that use Time(Before Covid, During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the three time points.  

2. GRIPS score as a dependent measure in a regression with Time  (During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the two time points.  

3. Nicholson et al. (2002) domain-specific risk scales (6 of them) as the dependent measurse in a regression with Time  (During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the two time points.  

3. Summed frequency/magnitude measure where the participant receives a sum z-score across all items. Thus it measures risk attitudes relative to others. This serve as the dependent measurse in a regression with Time  (During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the two time points.  

4. Identification if it is actually the Covid-19 outbreak that drive the possible effects: Use the summed attitudes toward the outbreak as predictors of the different risk measures. 

SWEDISH SAMPLE:

1. Evalutions of the prospects (WTPs or CEs) provide a raw estimate of their risk attitude and serve as the dependent variable in a regression that use Time ( During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the two time points.  NOTE: There is no data for collected on this population on monetary prospects before. 

2. GRIPS score as a dependent measure in a regression with Time  (During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the two time points.  

3. Nicholson et al. (2002) domain-specific risk scales (6 of them) as the dependent measurse in a regression with Time  (Before Outbreak: During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the two time points.  NOTE: There is data collected for this population (e.g., Ågren et al., 2019) that will be used as comparison!

3. Summed frequency/magnitude measure where the participant receives a sum z-score across all items. Thus it measures risk attitudes relative to others. This serve as the dependent measurse in a regression with Time  (During Covid Outbreak, After clear peak decline) as a fixed factor and numeracy, age, educational level, and income as covariates to account for any sample differences between the two time points.  

4. Identification if it is actually the Covid-19 outbreak that drive the possible effects: Use the summed attitudes toward the outbreak as predictors of the different risk measures.

attributes.description: The purpose of this research is to examine White and Black American's expectations regarding prototypic scenarios of cultural appropriation, of cultural celebration, and of racism.

q2.value:
Black Participants will be more likely than White participants to describe appropriative scenarios as appropriative and prejudice scenarios as prejudiced/racist.

Cultural appropriation and prejudice scenarios that involve White perpetrators using Black culture/interacting with Black actors will be perceived as more appropriative/prejudiced.

Perpetrator Race X Participant Race Interaction Effect on Perceptions of Cultural Appropriation.  For the cultural appropriation scenarios, the tendency to see White perpetrators as more appropriative then Black perpetrators will be strongest among Black participants.

Perpetrator Race X Participant Race Interaction Effect on Perceptions of Cultural Celebration.  For the cultural appropriation scenarios, White participants will be more likely than Black participants to see White perpetrator actions as “celebratory.”

Perpetrator Race X Participant Race Interaction Effect on Perceptions of Prejudice/Racism. For the prejudice scenarios, the tendency for White perpetrators to be perceived as more racist than Black perpetrators will be strongest among Black participants.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q5.value: Coders will not know the treatment group to which participants have been assigned.

question.value: This is a within-subjects design, where participants will be presented with culturally appropriative scenarios and racist scenarios in a counterbalanced order. Participants will also be presented with two filler scenarios.

q7.value: Scenarios will be presented to participants in a random counterbalanced order via Qualtrics.com.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be able to sign up for the study via Amazon's Mechanical Turk Workforce. Participants will be compensated $1.00 for their time. Participants from the general population will be given equal opportunity to sign up for participation in this study. However, due to the nature of the study, we are only interested in recruiting adult subjects (i.e., 18 years or older), and who self-identify as Black American or White American.

q12.value: Assuming a medium effect size (ΔR2 = .05), α = .05, and 80% power in a 2 x 2 analysis of variance (ANOVA) model, a desired sample size of 182 was estimated. We will oversample by 50 participants to account for possible participant exclusions.

question.value:
We will manipulate the scenario type. 

Participants will be asked to read and evaluate 8 scenarios: 4 appropriation scenarios, 2 racism scenarios, and 2 filler scenarios.

In the appropriation scenarios, each participant will receive 2 White perpetrator and 2 Black perpetrator versions. 

In the racism scenarios, each participant will receive 1 White perpetrator and 1 Black perpetrator scenario.

The 2 fillers will be the same for everyone. 

Participants will receive the following instructions:  

In this study, we are interested in your perception of various interpersonal interactions. You will read a series of brief stories or episodes, and then provide your reactions to them. Although the stories are fictitious, pretend that you are there in the situation watching the behaviors as they occur.” 

INSTRUCTIONS RIGHT BEFORE STORIES APPEAR: You will be asked to read a number of fictitious story episodes.  In each of the stories, we would like you to form an impression of the people involved, paying CLOSE ATTENTION TO THE ACTIONS AND PERSONALITY of one individual whom we refer to as the ACTOR. This individual's name will appear in ALL CAPITAL LETTERS.  

IMMEDIATELY AFTER you read each story, we would like you to indicate what you feel are the most NOTICEABLE QUALITIES DISPLAYED DURING THIS SCENARIO.  You may list traits, patterns, behavioral styles, or attitudes.  Limit yourself to three, picking those that are most noticeable to you.  Please LIST AT LEAST TWO.  


Appropriation Vignettes

1. Appropriation Vignette 1: The founder and CEO of an international beauty company, has recently launched a new hair product (selling outgroup- relevant hair products to ingroup buyers)

2. Appropriation Vignette 2: A novelist writes a book about an outgroup protagonist.

3. Appropriation Vignette 3: An artist debuts a solo exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art which depicts outgroup subjects and themes.

4. Appropriation Vignette 4: A chef opens a new restaurant that serves outgroup cuisine.

Filler Vignettes

1. Filler Vignette 1: Two men are driving to work when they witness a minor traffic accident. One man expresses concerns about feeling vulnerable to everyday dangers of the world, including accidents, disease, and terrorists. 

2. Filler Vignette 2: Two women are out shopping for one of the women’s boyfriends. One women advises her friend not to purchase a jacket because of the hideous color. 



Prejudice Vignettes 

1. Prejudice Vignette 1: The host at a restaurant tells a customer that the restaurant will close early due to a slow night and then tells a friend on the phone that it will be a busy night at the restaurant.

2. Prejudice Vignette 2: Two men waiting for the same job interview are chatting when one says, "I wouldn't worry about it [the interview], I don't think they will hire someone like you."

AFTER participants give open-ended responses to all the scenarios, participants will be represented with each scenario, and complete the following ratings: 

Closed Ended Measures (Counterbalance order of presentation) (1- Not at all; 7 – Very much)

o To what extent do you think this/the scenarios you read is/are a case of cultural appropriation? (e.g. taking from, stealing from, commodifying, lifting from, encroaching upon Black/White culture)

o To what extent do you think this/the scenarios you read is/are a case of cultural celebration? (e.g. celebrating, commemorating, honoring, appreciating Black/White culture)

o To what extent do you think this/the scenarios you read is a case of racism? (e.g. prejudice, discrimination, racial bias)


Second,  coders will independently code for presence of themes in open ended responses:

 0  – No Presence of Theme, 1 – Some Presence of Theme,  2  – Strong Presence of Theme]

o To what extent do you think this response is discussing a case of cultural appropriation? (e.g. taking from, stealing from, commodifying, lifting from, encroaching upon Black/White culture)

o To what extent do you think this response is discussing is a case of cultural celebration? (e.g. celebrating, commemorating, honoring, appreciating Black/White culture)

o To what extent do you think this response is discussing a case of racism? (e.g. prejudice, discrimination, racial bias)
Responses to dependent measures will be submitted to a 2(Perpetrator Race-between subjects) X 2(Participant Race)

attributes.title: Defining Cheating Using Multiple Models
attributes.description: Extradyadic romantic behavior in committed relationships, referred to here as “cheating,” is a common occurrence. For the purposes of this study, we define cheating as romantic or sexual behaviors that occur outside of a committed romantic relationship and that violate the expectations of the relationship. This definition can be broken down into two parts: the behavior that occurred and the judgment of whether that behavior constitutes cheating. Previous research has explored these two different parts separately, but have not included both parts of the definition, thus limiting the utility of their measures as they do not encapsulate the full construct. Given the inconsistent theoretical approaches and lack of full inclusion of the definition of cheating in research, our goal for the current project is to investigate whether a conceptualization of cheating that includes explicit cheating behaviors and the judgments of the behaviors as cheating fits the underlying structure of the construct. Specifically, we plan to investigate both explicit cheating behaviors as dimensional, as has been the standard in the research literature, and the judgments of the cheating behaviors as both a categorical and dimensional judgment.

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1: We hypothesize a one-factor dimensional model will provide a good fit for our measure of explicit factors of cheating behaviors.
Hypothesis 2: We hypothesize the categorical and dimensional aspects of our measure of judgments will be strongly related to each other and the model will result in good fit to the data. 
Research Question 1: Will biological sex, history with cheating, and age be significant moderators to the relationship between the categorical and dimensional aspects of judgments?
Research Question 2: Will there be biological sex and age cohort differences in endorsement of explicit behaviors?
Research Question 3: Will we replicate previously found associations between history with cheating and depression, anxiety, and relationship satisfaction?

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Single time point survey

q9.value: Data is currently being collected. Only current knowledge of the data is how many participants have taken the survey.

question.value: Participants will be recruited online through CloudResearch (MTurk/TurkPrime). Participants will be paid .$90 for agreeing to participate. Only participants who are older than 18 years of age, speak English fluently, and currently live within the United States will be allowed to participate. CloudResearch allows us to place filters on those characteristics so our study will only appear to those who meet the criteria. We plan to include participants who have cheated as well as those who have not. While we could create having a history of cheating as an inclusionary criterion, we decided against doing so because we believe it could change our results. Specifically, since the definition of cheating appears to vary amongst individuals, it is likely that some participants will have participated in some cheating behaviors as defined by us that they would not think of if they were asked to self-select into the study based on their past behaviors.

q11.value: We plan to administer this questionnaire to 1,000 individuals through CloudResearch. Not every participant in our sample will have engaged in cheating behaviors. Due to this, we chose a high number of required participants to help ensure we have adequate power for our analyses.

q12.value: Not every participant in our sample will have engaged in cheating behaviors. Due to this, we chose a high number of required participants to help ensure we have adequate power for our analyses.

question.value: There are no manipulated variables because it is observational.

Explicit behaviors. To assess the explicit behaviors piece of our definition, participants will be asked, "Please indicate which actions you have engaged in while in an exclusive romantic relationship.” They will then be presented with our list of potential cheating behaviors and their response options. For items that involve someone else, we will clarify, “’Someone other than my partner’ refers to a person to whom you could be attracted” in order to focus exclusively on behaviors that potentially reflect cheating since, for example, riding in a car with a same-sex co-worker would not approximate cheating behavior but riding with an opposite-sex coworker could, for a heterosexual participant. We will ask participants to report on all past behavior, rather than from some specific time period (e.g., the last six months) to capture more variability in cheating behaviors, since cheating is a relatively low base-rate phenomenon in any one arbitrarily determined time referent. 
For the response options, we plan to use a 3-point rating scale: 0 = “Did not participate in this behavior”, 1 = “Participated in this behavior on only one occasion”, and 2 = “Participated in this behavior on more than one occasion.” Often, researchers have used dichotomous response options (e.g., “Yes” or “No”) when assessing cheating behavior. We chose to use an ordinal scale because it provides more information by allowing for the property of magnitude. This additional variability is important statistically in creating data that are more appropriate for our chosen models which attempt to discern underlying latent factors. Additionally, assessing for frequency aligns with potential conceptualizations of cheating behaviors (i.e., dimensional and hybrid models).
Additionally, to give us the ability to do more nuanced investigation of motivation, intent, and serial cheating in future studies, we plan to include further response options for those who endorse an item. Specifically, if a participant chooses “Did not participate in this behavior,” they will then be presented with the options of 0 = “Did not participate in this behavior because there was no opportunity” and 1 = “Did not participate in this behavior despite the opportunity to do so because I did not want to” (Luo, Cartun, & Snider, 2010; Wiederman & Hurd, 1999). If a participant chooses “Participated in this behavior on more than one occasion,” they will then be presented with the options of 1 = “Participated in this behavior on more than one occasion with the same person”, and 2 = ‘‘Participated in this behavior with different people” (Luo, Cartun, & Snider, 2010; Wiederman & Hurd, 1999); in this case, we will allow participants to select both options, if applicable. Additionally, for those who indicate they have participated in any of these behaviors on more than one occasion, we will include the item “Please indicate the number of times you have participated in this behavior” with an open-ended response. We do not currently plan to analyze these additional response options in the proposed project but believe they will be useful in other studies and for the future utility of this measure. 

Judgment of behaviors. Our operational definition of cheating includes the idea that whether a behavior is cheating is determined by the expectations and rules of the particular relationship. In order to account for this aspect of our operational definition, we plan to present the previously described items to participants a second time, this time asking them first “Do you consider this behavior to be cheating” with response options 0 = “No” and 1 = “Yes.” Participants will then be asked, “How serious do you consider the participation in this behavior?” on a scale of 1 = “Not serious at all” to 10 “Extremely serious.”

The final questionnaire will consist of demographic questions, the measure mentioned above, measures related to previously established negative consequences of cheating and validity questions (see Appendix C for proposed validity items). Included in the demographic items will an open ended question asking for the participant’s age and the items, “Have you done anything you consider to be cheating?” and “Has a partner done anything you consider to be cheating?” to assess participants’ history with cheating. All participants will complete the center for epidemiologic studies depression scale – short form (CESD-SF; Martens et al., 2006) to assess depressive symptoms and the generalized anxiety disorder 7 (GAD 7; Spitzer, Kroenke, Williams, & Lowe, 2006) for anxious symptoms. For individuals who indicate they are currently in a romantic relationship, we will also include the couples satisfaction index (CSI-4; Funk & Rogge, 2007; see Appendix D for other proposed measures), as well as items assessing cheating in their current relationship (“Have you done anything in your current relationship that you consider to be cheating?” and “Has your current partner done anything in your relationship that you consider to be cheating?”).

Hypothesis 1. To address our first hypothesis, we plan to run a confirmatory factor analysis for a one-factor dimensional model. While it is common to use exploratory factor analysis in the beginning stages of measure creation, we have chosen to do a confirmatory factor analysis because we theorize that there is one factor underlying explicit cheating behaviors. If our one-factor model does not provide good fit, we plan to run additional analyses to determine the best fitting factor structure.  
We plan to evaluate model fit using the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA; RMSEA <0.08 indicates adequate fit), comparative fit index (CFI; CFI >0.95 indicates good fit), Tucker-Lewis index (TLI; TLI >0.95 indicates good fit) and standardized root mean square residual (SRMR; SRMR <0.08 indicates good fit).

Hypothesis 2. To address our second hypothesis, we plan to run a confirmatory factor analysis of our proposed model (see Figure 1). We plan to analyze model fit using the RMSEA, CFI, TLI, and SRMR. Once the model has been adequately fitted, we plan to evaluate the relationship between the two aspects of judgments.

Research question 1.  To address our first research question, we plan to include three different moderation analyses for our judgments model, one each for biological sex, history with cheating, and age. For biological sex, we plan to use “men” and “women” as our categories. For history with cheating, we plan to use “transgressor only”, “victim only”, “both transgressor and victim”, and “neither transgressor nor victim” as our categories, based off participant answers to the demographic questions concerning history of cheating that every participant will complete. For age, we plan to create the categories either based on standard social generations (i.e., baby boomers, generation X, etc.) or developmental stages (i.e., emerging adulthood, middle age, etc.) depending on the distribution of ages we see once we have collected the data.  

Research questions 2 and 3. For research question two, we plan to analyze descriptive statistics and do independent samples t-tests to determine if any differences between biological sex and the previously specified age cohorts represent statistically significant differences both in overall prevalence rates of cheating behaviors and in prevalence rates of specific explicit behaviors. For research question three, we plan to run correlation coefficients to determine the relationship between having a history with cheating and depressive and anxious symptoms. Further, for those participants who are currently in a relationship, we plan to run correlations between cheating having occurred in the current relationship and relationship satisfaction.

q18.value: All variables with an already established coding system for the scale will be coded as is standard for that scale. For biological sex, we plan to use “men” and “women” as our categories with "women" as our reference category. For history with cheating, we plan to use “transgressor only”, “victim only”, “both transgressor and victim”, and “neither transgressor nor victim” as our categories ("neither transgressor nor victim" as reference category), based off participant answers to the demographic questions concerning history of cheating that every participant will complete. For age, we plan to create the categories either based on standard social generations (i.e., baby boomers, generation X, etc.) or developmental stages (i.e., emerging adulthood, middle age, etc.) depending on the distribution of ages we see once we have collected the data.

q19.value: We plan to evaluate model fit using the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA; RMSEA <0.08 indicates adequate fit), comparative fit index (CFI; CFI >0.95 indicates good fit), Tucker-Lewis index (TLI; TLI >0.95 indicates good fit) and standardized root mean square residual (SRMR; SRMR <0.08 indicates good fit).

q20.value: We will verify that each participant responded to all necessary items.

q21.value: We plan to ensure that missing data is missing at random. If it is missing at random, we plan to include it.

Hypothesis 1. To address our first hypothesis, we plan to run a confirmatory factor analysis for a one-factor dimensional model. While it is common to use exploratory factor analysis in the beginning stages of measure creation, we have chosen to do a confirmatory factor analysis because we theorize that there is one factor underlying explicit cheating behaviors. If our one-factor model does not provide good fit, we plan to run additional analyses to determine the best fitting factor structure.  
We plan to evaluate model fit using the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA; RMSEA <0.08 indicates adequate fit), comparative fit index (CFI; CFI >0.95 indicates good fit), Tucker-Lewis index (TLI; TLI >0.95 indicates good fit) and standardized root mean square residual (SRMR; SRMR <0.08 indicates good fit).

Hypothesis 2. To address our second hypothesis, we plan to run a confirmatory factor analysis of our proposed model (see Figure 1). We plan to analyze model fit using the RMSEA, CFI, TLI, and SRMR. Once the model has been adequately fitted, we plan to evaluate the relationship between the two aspects of judgments.

Research question 1.  To address our first research question, we plan to include three different moderation analyses for our judgments model, one each for biological sex, history with cheating, and age. For biological sex, we plan to use “men” and “women” as our categories. For history with cheating, we plan to use “transgressor only”, “victim only”, “both transgressor and victim”, and “neither transgressor nor victim” as our categories, based off participant answers to the demographic questions concerning history of cheating that every participant will complete. For age, we plan to create the categories either based on standard social generations (i.e., baby boomers, generation X, etc.) or developmental stages (i.e., emerging adulthood, middle age, etc.) depending on the distribution of ages we see once we have collected the data.  

Research questions 2 and 3. For research question two, we plan to analyze descriptive statistics and do independent samples t-tests to determine if any differences between biological sex and the previously specified age cohorts represent statistically significant differences both in overall prevalence rates of cheating behaviors and in prevalence rates of specific explicit behaviors. For research question three, we plan to run correlation coefficients to determine the relationship between having a history with cheating and depressive and anxious symptoms. Further, for those participants who are currently in a relationship, we plan to run correlations between cheating having occurred in the current relationship and relationship satisfaction.
